ratings.comment: Let's cut to the chase: Professor Lee is terrible at teaching. However, it is critical to go to lectures because he hints at the proofs that he will put on the exams. Other than this, complete the homework and you should be fine for the class.

He taught straight out of the book during lectures so they aren't mandatory. I always went because he hints at test questions and one time told us one of the same exact proofs that was on the final. The class isn't much work, and I don't think the material is hard if you have a good professor.

He reads straight from the book during lectures and goes off on long winded, often useless proofs. He gives little to no test expectations. Would avoid if possible. I thought the class was worse than math 222. Midterm is 35% and final is 45%.

Donghyun is a nice guy but his lectures are only useful for trying to figure out what proof problem(s) will be on the exams. Weekly homework, exams are worth a total of 80% of your final grade. Like other reviewers have said, pray for a good TA because Donghyun's teaching style is fast-paced and proof-based, not example-based.

Donghyun gets a bad rep but he teaches the material well and understandably. He did miss a couple lectures and was a minute or two late everyday though which was a little frustrating. The class is almost all based on the midterm and final so there is a lot riding on them and he grades them somewhat harshly.

He reads everything from the textbook. That is not an exaggeration, he carries the textbook and constantly looks at it during his lecture. The midterm and final make or break your grade too. Expect to self teach a lot, and pray you have a good TA.
Lectures are extremely hard to follow and don't help much. Hope for a good TA or it will be a hard class.

The tests were graded poorly but once I looked at my actual exam there were points taken off that shouldn't have been. I got back probably around 20 points back on the tests. So if you have him as a professor make sure to look through your exam. I also would recommend going to his office hours because he is way better at explaining things 1 to 1.

Overall, one of the worst classes I've ever taken at UW was with Donghyung. Lectures are the equivalent of watching boring YouTube videos. He never interacts with students. You are better off reading the book and attending discussion to learn. Exams were 85% of the course grade. Exams are graded whimsically and with no rubric. I don't recommend him
He doesn't really go above and beyond, but he teaches the material and makes it pretty clear what you should know for tests. Homework prepares you for the test. Eza was a great TA, maybe that helped.

Doesn't convey anything of use beyond reading directly from the textbook. Also, his communication is quite terrible as far as exam times and what to study, and he comes across as quite rude. Didn't release any practice exams or practice problems whatsoever, and exams were based around memorizing proofs. Avoid if possible or hope for a good TA.

Donghyun means well but his lectures are dry. He reads straight from the textbook, and does not create any new examples for better understanding. His tests and homeworks are very proof centered, even thought the class is for non-math majors.

He writes so fast its terrible. I'm usually half a chalk board behind him which means I don't have time to actually understand what I'm writing. It sucks because you don't really know what is going on a lot of times. My friends and I will leave a lecture and honestly have no idea what we just wrote down. The homework helped me though.

He's not bad, especially for a young-ish professor from Asia. He's not that hard to understand. His lectures are pretty fast-paced and doesn't usually stop for questions, but he also goes over a lot of homework in class. The homework can be really hard but he's an easy grader. To be fair, the textbook itself is super intense. (Calculus - Spivak)

Donghyun Lee is a good professor. The only thing I can complain is that he does not know how to use chalk; always make noise. Except that, he is smart, helpful and clear. The test is easy and grading is fair. (And I hope the final on Friday will also be easy).
